title.value: Pre-training Protein Structure Encoder via Siamese Diffusion Trajectory Prediction
title.justification: This title accurately encapsulates the core methodology and objective of the research presented.
title.quote: Pre-training Protein Structure Encoder via Siamese Diffusion Trajectory Prediction

extractions.description: The paper proposes a novel method called Siamese Diffusion Trajectory Prediction (SiamDiff) for the pre-training of protein structure encoders. This method leverages multimodal diffusion processes to build correlated views of protein structures and sequences, maximizing the mutual information between these views to enhance protein representation learning.

type.justification: The study involves extensive experiments and evaluations of the proposed SiamDiff method on various datasets and benchmark tasks to demonstrate its effectiveness.
type.quote: Experimental results on EC and ATOM3D benchmarks show that the performance of SiamDiff is consistently competitive on all benchmark tasks, compared with existing baselines.

name.justification: The focus of the paper is on learning effective representations of protein structures for downstream tasks.
name.quote: structure-based protein representation pre-training is recently gaining interest but remains largely unexplored

name.justification: The paper explores self-supervised methods for pre-training protein structures.
name.quote: Compared to extensively studied sequence-based protein self-supervised learning like protein language models

name.justification: The proposed method is based on diffusion processes for generating correlated views of protein structures and sequences.
name.quote: SiamDiff employs the multimodal diffusion process as a faithful simulation of the structure-sequence co-diffusion trajectory

name.justification: The method leverages mutual information maximization between different views of the same protein, a concept rooted in contrastive learning.
name.quote: Recent self-supervised learning approaches learn informative representations by maximizing mutual information (MI) between representations of multiple views of the same object with shared information

name.justification: SiamDiff is the central model proposed and evaluated in the paper.
name.quote: we propose the Siamese Diffusion Trajectory Prediction (SiamDiff) method

is_contributed.justification: SiamDiff is the novel method introduced and contributed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose the Siamese Diffusion Trajectory Prediction (SiamDiff) method

is_executed.justification: The model was executed as part of the experiments conducted in the paper.
is_executed.quote: SiamDiff outperforms all baselines except Multiview Contrast

is_compared.justification: The performance of SiamDiff is compared against multiple baseline models.
is_compared.quote: Experimental results verify that SiamDiff can consistently achieve competitive performance on all benchmark tasks

name.justification: This dataset is used for evaluating the effectiveness of protein function prediction models.
name.quote: Experimental results on EC and ATOM3D benchmarks show that the performance of SiamDiff is consistently competitive on all benchmark tasks

referenced_paper_title.value: Structure-based protein function prediction using graph convolutional networks.

name.justification: This benchmark dataset is used for various structural prediction tasks in the experiments.
name.quote: Experimental results on EC and ATOM3D benchmarks

referenced_paper_title.value: ATOM3D: Tasks on molecules in three dimensions.
referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset is referenced regarding its composition of multiple structural tasks for validation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: the Residue Identity task from ATOM3D (Townshend et al., 2020)

name.justification: This dataset is used for pre-training the models on massive protein structures.
name.quote: Following Zhang et al. (2022), we pre-train our models with the AlphaFold protein structure database (Jumper et al., 2021; Varadi et al., 2021)

referenced_paper_title.value: Highly accurate protein structure prediction with AlphaFold.
referenced_paper_title.justification: This prominent dataset is referenced due to its use in pre-training protein structure encoders.
referenced_paper_title.quote: AlphaFold protein structure database (Jumper et al., 2021)

name.justification: This dataset of predicted protein structures is also used for pre-training the models.
name.quote: Following Zhang et al. (2022), we pre-train our models with the AlphaFold protein structure database (Jumper et al., 2021; Varadi et al., 2021), including both 365K proteomewide predicted structures and 440K Swiss-Prot (Consortium, 2021) predicted structures.

referenced_paper_title.value: UniProt: the universal protein knowledgebase in 2021.
referenced_paper_title.justification: Swiss-Prot is a widely recognized dataset referenced to highlight the scale of the pre-training.

name.justification: The models and experiments in the paper were implemented using PyTorch.
name.quote: These methods are developed based on PyTorch and TorchDrug

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library.
referenced_paper_title.justification: PyTorch is a standard tool used for the development of the models in this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: These methods are developed based on PyTorch and TorchDrug

name.quote: These methods are developed based on PyTorch and TorchDrug
